clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Aminoglycosides in Hypotensive Septic Oncology Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluating the Impact of Aminoglycosides in Hypotensive Septic Oncology Patients

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the impact of aminoglycosides in hypotensive septic oncologic patients. In the oncologic patient population, sepsis is a major health concern due to high mortality rates and healthcare costs. Prior research shows aminoglycosides antibiotics are frequently used to treat sepsis, but their clinical impact in hypotensive oncology patients upon the progression of sepsis is not known.

detailed_description.textblock:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVE:
I. To assess the impact of beta-lactam (BL) + aminoglycoside (AG) combination therapy in hypotensive septic oncology patients.
OUTLINE:
Patients' medical charts are reviewed retrospectively.

primary_outcome.description: Defined as a mean arterial pressure > 65 mmHg not requiring vasopressors and sustained for >= 24 hours.

arm_group.description: Patients' medical charts are reviewed retrospectively.

study_pop.textblock: Oncology patients with sepsis and hypotension treated at The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center from January 1, 2019 to December 31, 2019

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients (age >= 18 years) with a diagnosis of sepsis during the index hospital admission identified by International classification of diseases (ICD)-10 codes (as specified below) receiving BL antibiotics within 6 hours prior to or following the onset of hypotension
- To be included in the AG group, patients must have received at least 1 dose of intravenous (IV) tobramycin or amikacin in addition to the BL therapy within the above time period
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age < 18 years
- Receipt of IV AG outside of the above time frame in the AG group or receipt of IV AG within 48 hours prior to or following the onset of hypotension in the BL backbone group
- Pregnancy
- Patients not receiving therapy with BL antibiotics

link.description: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center
